questions.question: Patients with metachromatic leukodystrophy will have which of the following enzymedeficiency?
questions.explanation: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive condition caused by the deficiency ofarylsulfatase A.The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. These sulfatidescan contribute to white matter injury, demyelination, and gliosis.Macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm are scattered throughout the white matter. They containmetachromatic material, which can be detected in the urine and peripheral nerves when stainedwith toluidine blue.

questions.question: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in patients with Krabbe disease?
questions.explanation: Krabbe disease is due to the deficiency of galactosylceramidase.The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such asstiffness and weakness. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows lossof myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma andaround blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following diseases will have ceramide trihexoside accumulation?
questions.explanation: Ceramide trihexoside (also known as globotriaosylceramide) is accumulated in Fabry disease.The enzyme defect seen in this disease is α-galactosidase A.172Clinical features:• Painful acroparaesthesia•⚫ Hypohidrosis• Abdominal cramping•• Diarrhea• Small petechiae around the umbilicus• Lenticular opacities•Corneal dystrophy

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about Niemann-Pick disease?

options.A: Inherited deficiency of aryl sulfatase is present

questions.explanation: Niemann-Pick disease types A and B are two related disorders that are characterized by lysosomalaccumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase.The disease is typically inherited as an autosomal recessive condition on chromosome 11.Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceralaccumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting, and early death within the first 3 years oflife.Type B disease patients have organomegaly, but generally no central nervous system involvement.They usually survive into adulthood.

questions.question: Given below is an electron microscopy picture of lysosomes. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: Electron microscopy showing zebra bodies is suggestive of Niemann-Pick disease.Zebra bodies are engorged secondary lysosomes that contain membranous cytoplasmic bodiesresembling concentric lamellated myelin figures. Similar zebra bodies can also be seen inmucopolysaccharidoses.

questions.question: 167Which of the following is false about mucopolysaccharidosis?

options.A: Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
options.B: Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase
options.C: They are inherited as autosomal recessive traits, except Hunter syndrome
options.D: Hunter syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant disease

questions.explanation: All the mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as autosomal-recessive traits except Huntersyndrome. It is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease.The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) are a group of closely related syndromes that result fromgenetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation ofmucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans).Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissues. In the absenceof enzymes involved in their degradation, they accumulate within lysosomes in various tissues andorgans of the body. Two among these are:•• Hurler syndrome - deficiency of α-L-iduronidase⚫ Hunter syndrome - deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase

questions.question: Which glycogen storage disorder is a lysosomal storage disease?
questions.explanation: 174Glycogen storage disorder type II, also called Pompe disease, is the only glycogen storagedisease with a defect in lysosomal metabolism.It is an autosomal-recessive metabolic disorder. It is caused by the accumulation of glycogen inthe lysosome due to deficiency of the lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase enzyme.

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy presented with severe pain in his left leg which worsened over the last fewmonths. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and developmental delays were noticed. Labsrevealed the following findings on light and oil immersion respectively of the bone marrowaspiration. Which of the following is deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and bone marrow aspiration images showing necrotic bone with lack ofosteocytes in the lacunae (Image A) and Gaucher cells (Image B)are suggestive of Gaucher'sdisease. This condition has a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.Gaucher cells are plump macrophages that characteristically have a crumpled tissue paperappearance (Image B) of the cytoplasm. It is due to the accumulation of glucocerebrosides.They can be seen in Virchow-Robin spaces (perivascular fluid-filled cavities that surroundperforating arteries and veins in the brain parenchyma) in patients with cerebral involvement.

questions.question: A 1-year-old child presents with growth retardation and abdominal distension. Onexamination, the child has characteristic doll-like facies with thin extremities. Bloodinvestigations reveal hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. USGabdomen shows hepatomegaly and renomegaly. What deficiency causes the given clinicalcondition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose6 phosphatase enzyme.The condition usually manifests as:175• Failure to thrive• Stunted growth.• Hepatomegaly• RenomegalyHypoglycemia is due to the failure of glucose mobilization which often leads to convulsions. Lacticacidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia result from deranged glucose metabolism. Manypatients also develop gout, skin xanthomas, and bleeding tendency (due to platelet dysfunction).With treatment, most patients survive and develop late complications (e.g., hepatic adenomas).

questions.question: Which enzyme is deficient in McArdle's syndrome?
questions.explanation: McArdle's syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase.In the skeletal muscles, as opposed to the liver, glycogen is used predominantly as a source ofenergy during physical activity. If enzymes hydrolyzing glucose are deficient, there will be anaccumulation of glycogen in the muscles. This will cause muscle weakness due to impaired energyproduction.Enzyme deficiencies leading to muscle glycogen storage include:• McArdle disease/type V glycogenosis - deficiency of muscle phosphorylase•⚫ Type VII glycogen storage disease - deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinaseTypically, individuals with myopathic forms present with muscle cramps after exercise. This isbecause lactate levels in the blood fail to rise after exercise due to a block in glycolysis.176
